verses.text: Praise the LORD! For it is good to sing praises to our God; for it is pleasant, and praise is fitting.
verses.comment: The psalm begins with an exhortation to joyful praise. The idea of praise being 'fitting' echoes the human response to God's goodness, a theme central throughout Scripture.

verses.text: The LORD builds up Jerusalem; he gathers the scattered of Israel.
verses.comment: God's gathering of Israel foresees the fulfillment of promises of restoration. Spiritually, building Jerusalem hints at God's plan to unite His people, prefiguring the Church as spiritual Israel (see Eph. 2:19-22).

verses.text: He heals the brokenhearted, and binds up their wounds.
verses.comment: This verse foreshadows Christ’s ministry to the wounded and the broken, as quoted by Jesus in Luke 4:18, showing the fulfillment of prophecy and highlighting God’s merciful compassion.

verses.text: He counts the number of the stars; he gives names to all of them.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty and intimate care are shown in His knowledge of creation, recalling His covenant with Abraham and promises reaching fulfillment in Christ.

verses.text: Great is our Lord, and abundant in power; his understanding is beyond measure.
verses.comment: Echoing God’s infinite wisdom as seen in both Old and New Testaments; such descriptions encourage awe and humble trust.

verses.text: The LORD lifts up the humble; he casts the wicked down to the ground.
verses.comment: A theme reminiscent of Christ’s teaching: those who are humble are lifted up, foreshadowing the reversal of worldly status in God’s kingdom.

verses.text: Sing to the LORD with thanksgiving; make melody to our God on the harp.
verses.comment: The worship of God in song and thanksgiving is a practice that continues from temple worship to the ongoing tradition of liturgical praise.

verses.text: He covers the heavens with clouds, prepares rain for the earth, makes grass grow on the hills.
verses.comment: God’s providence in nature points to His sustaining power; an image often used to highlight His continual care.

verses.text: He gives to the beasts their food, and to the young ravens that cry.
verses.comment: A reminder of God’s intimate provision and concern for all creation, paralleling Jesus' teaching on God’s care.

verses.text: He does not delight in the strength of the horse nor take pleasure in the legs of a man.
verses.comment: God’s favor is not earned by physical strength or human achievement, contrasting with worldly measures of value.

verses.text: The LORD takes pleasure in those who fear him, in those who hope in his steadfast love.
verses.comment: Emphasizes reverence and trust in God above all else; the theme of faith and hope is central to the Christian life.

verses.text: Praise the LORD, O Jerusalem! Praise your God, O Zion!
verses.comment: A call to worship addressed to God’s chosen city, now spiritually understood as representing those united in worship.

verses.text: For he strengthens the bars of your gates; he blesses your children within you.
verses.comment: God’s protection and blessing extend to community, prefiguring divine safeguarding of believers and their families.

verses.text: He makes peace within your borders; he fills you with the finest wheat.
verses.comment: Speaks of both physical and spiritual peace and provision—a theme fulfilled in Christ, the true Bread from heaven (John 6:32-35).

verses.text: He sends out his command to the earth; his word runs swiftly.
verses.comment: God’s Word is active and effective, a concept central to understanding the power of Scripture and its fulfillment in the living Word, Christ.

verses.text: He gives snow like wool; he scatters frost like ashes.
verses.comment: God’s control over nature symbolizes purity and transformation, both literal and spiritual.

verses.text: He throws down his hail like crumbs; who can withstand his cold?
verses.comment: Shows God’s power and the limitations of human strength in the face of His might.

verses.text: He sends out his word and melts them; he causes his wind to blow, and the waters flow.
verses.comment: The power of God’s word is able to change and renew all creation, echoing themes of spiritual renewal and the efficacy of God’s commands.

verses.text: He declares his word to Jacob, his statutes and ordinances to Israel.
verses.comment: Revelation was given to God’s chosen, signifying a privileged intimacy and responsibility, seen also in Christ’s giving of new commands to His followers.

verses.text: He has not dealt thus with any other nation; they do not know his ordinances. Praise the LORD!
verses.comment: God’s unique covenant relates to Israel, but through Christ, this blessing is extended to all nations (see Gal. 3:28), fulfilling the promise of inclusion and unity under God’s one people.
